elements.title: Cover Page of S|three's Annual Report and Accounts 2022

data.value: This image appears to be the cover page of S|three's Annual Report and Accounts 2022. The design features a magenta/purple background with white text stating 'Uniquely positioned to serve a changing world' as the main headline. The image shows a silhouette of a person in profile view lit with blue lighting, appearing to be looking at or working with a laptop or screen. The overall design is modern and minimalist.

SThree’s Annual Report and Accounts 2022 is our primary report to shareholders. It provides an overview of the performance of the Group for the year ended 30 November 2022, disclosures relating to our financial, operational, environmental and social performance, and detail on our strategy.
See our full reporting network suite, including our ESG Impact Report and summary of notices and policies, at sthree.com.

data.value: To be the #1 STEM talent provider in the best STEM markets

To sustain its conversion ratio at 21% or higher.
To reduce scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions by 25% compared to 2019.

elements.title: Annual Report and Accounts 2022 for SThree plc
Our People - Find, develop and retain great people

data.value: Developing future culture programmes, investing in capabilities and tools, implementing Future Office plans, introducing new operating models, leadership investments, Purpose rollout for managers, talent mobility measures.
New employee onboarding programme launched, including Elements onboarding programme with 62,463 courses started and 56,424 completed.
Implemented sales compensation scheme across key markets (USA, Germany, Netherlands, UK and Japan) plus enhancements in base salaries and commission schemes.
Comprehensive review of recruitment and retention practices for continuous improvement.
sThree plc's Annual Report and Accounts 2022
Chair's governance statement, Board of Directors, Board roles and responsibilities
Timo Lehne appointed as permanent CEO; Anne Fahy stood down as Non-Executive Director and Chair of the Audit Committee; appointments of Elaine O’Donnell and Imogen Joss as Non-Executive Directors
Introduction of global share plan; engagement with local management and employees across various global offices
Elaine O’Donnell, Barrie Brien, Imogen Joss

data.key: Chief Legal Officer and Company Secretary

data.value: The Chair ensures an effective Board, encourages communication, and facilitates relations between Executive and Non-Executive Directors.
The Chief Executive manages daily operations, implements strategy, and promotes company culture.
Provides support to the Chair, acts as a liaison for Non-Executive Directors, and leads annual appraisal of the Chair.
Scrutinize management, provide independent judgement, and are involved in remuneration and succession planning.
Advises on governance issues, facilitates Board communication, and manages inductions.

elements.title: Board and Committee Composition and Attendance

data.value: The Board comprises Executive and Non-Executive Directors with diversified skills.
James Bilefield, Timo Lehne, Andrew Beach, Denise Collis, and Barrie Brien attended all scheduled meetings.
Mark Dorman stepped down as a Director on 31 December 2021.
The Board reviews the performance of management and the operating and financial performance of the Group.
Establishing the Company’s purpose and values, setting strategy, determining risk appetite, ensuring appropriate risk management, and maintaining good governance.
The Board ensures plans are in place for orderly succession for appointments to the Board and senior management.
The Board usually meets formally eight times a year.
Certain powers are delegated to the Remuneration Committee, Audit & Risk Committee, and Nomination Committee.
Directors can obtain independent professional advice at the Company’s expense.
High priority given to engagement with shareholders as part of a comprehensive Investor Relations programme.
The Board views the AGM as an opportunity to communicate with investors.
The report discusses various initiatives aimed at improving employee engagement within the organization, led by the Board and management.
Dedicated Board sessions, focus groups, and analysis of survey results.
The commitment of the Board in addressing employee concerns and developing their leadership potential is emphasized.
Highlighting that employee views are valued and acted upon.
Feedback from employees indicating positive experiences.
Further focus group sessions will be held, aligning employee engagement with the business strategy.
Further develop internal communications, with particular emphasis on audience segmentation, to ensure appropriate and timely connections across different parts of the organisation.

data.key: Action taken during 2022 or planned for 2023
data.value: A key priority for the internal communications team has been reinforcement of key messages from the new CEO and ExCo. Top 100 calls, where the senior managers come together, are now conducted ona regular basis. We created and launched a strategic narrative at a global leadership event in October which was attended by most of our top 100 senior leaders. This was followed with a planned cascade, via a programme of local engagement events, for all employees, rolled out towards the end of 2022 and into 2023.
Provide greater clarity around the employee proposition.

data.key: Action taken during 2022 or planned for 2023
data.value: We developed a new People Promise. It provides a clear commitment about the experience we want to create for everyone who works at SThree. This was launched, and embedding commenced, during 2022. We also enhanced our employer value proposition (EVP), adjusting it to reflect different cultural nuances across our regions. This new EVP was created and launched in line with the brand refresh. A new careers site was launched, reinforcing the enhanced proposition. Looking forward to 2023, we will be developing new interventions reflecting the differing needs of those in sales and the core functions.
Continue to invest in L&D, particularly onboarding, manager effectiveness and leadership development.

data.key: Action taken during 2022 or planned for 2023
data.value: Our onboarding learning programme, Elements, which was shortlisted for Best Digital Induction and Best Use of Blended Learning awards at the Learning Technologies Awards, continues to grow with the course being accessed over 270,000 times since launch. A new Leading with Purpose programme was launched in H2 2022, combining a two-day programme with leadership assessments and coaching. It commenced with ExCo participation and then cascaded down to the Top 100. There will be quarterly follow up sessions in 2023.
Further work on career paths, progression and market- competitive rewards for both sales and core functions.

data.key: Action taken during 2022 or planned for 2023
data.value: Following the completion of the Global Grading project, all roles across the organisation are now aligned to the new framework. Our focus has turned to action planning to address inconsistencies and drive equity of career opportunity as well as the achievement of market competitive pay for all. Early initiatives included further investment in sales consultant base salaries in the USA, Germany, the Netherlands and the UK. We improved reward communications to colleagues in several markets, including a total reward statement in the USA, and uprated employee benefits communications in the UK. A share incentive plan for everyone at SThree was launched to promote a culture of collective ownership. Further activity, including a focus on career paths and opportunities for core functions, is being developed for 2023.
Provide greater openness around planned improvements to IT and operational infrastructure.

data.key: Action taken during 2022 or planned for 2023
data.value: The strategic investment in systems, that began in 2022, is delivering to plan. We established a communications stream to keep people briefed. Akey priority in 2023 will be to ensure that we engage with teams as they are directly impacted. We will complement this with broader communication that will allow people to understand the big picture as well as how and when changes will arrive locally.
SThree’s purpose is to bring skilled people together to build the future.
Barrie Brien 3/3, Denise Collis 3/3, Elaine O'Donnell WW
Mark Dorman stepped down, Timo Lehne appointed interim CEO and later confirmed as permanent CEO on April 28, 2022.
Anne Fahy resigned prior to meetings.
Imogen Joss joined the Committee after year end.
Aim for 40% female representation and one non-white minority ethnic member by December 2024.
Engaged with Russell Reynolds Associates for search.
Timo received a tailored induction programme.
All Directors are subject to annual re-election, although NEDs are typically expected to serve for an initial term of three years.
NEDs will normally serve no longer than nine years.
Directors receive a formal appointment letter identifying their responsibilities and expected minimum time commitment.
Each Director engages in a comprehensive induction programme tailored to individual needs.
Each year, the Board reviews performance and effectiveness, including of its committees and individual Directors.

Sales pathways have been defined using the Elements onboarding programme as a baseline, creating 118 different sales career journeys.
The new framework, Leading with Purpose, aims to increase capability in senior management, measured through a leadership index.
A grading scheme launched to standardise employee roles across the Group, improving management visibility.
Comprehensive training is essential for performance; upgrades include Identify, a talent development programme for women.
Femme Palette provided mentoring for 24 women at SThree to develop skills and capabilities.
New LMS features improved accessibility and drove 36,902 hours of learning in 2022.
Wellbeing pilot training covering 100 colleagues focused on resilience; positively received feedback influenced future training.
Introduced new compliance courses with 92% average completion rates.
Strategic focus on DE&I, with nine ERGs and various campaigns throughout 2022.
Launched to motivate employees by allowing them to buy and receive matching shares.
Enhanced training and engagement in health and safety across all regions.

data.value: Approved annual Committee programme/cycle of work.
Reviewed and recommended to the Board the full- and half-year financial results for publication.
Approved the external audit plan and reviewed the audit results.
Approved the IA plan and reviewed all reports/findings.
Reviewed the effectiveness of the IA function.
Reviewed the performance, independence and effectiveness of the external auditors.
Reviewed any non-audit services provided by the external auditors.
Reviewed the risk management and controls framework and effectiveness.
Considered the Code requirements concerning fair, balanced and understandable reporting.
Reviewed the Company’s going concern and long- term viability statements.
Reviewed work in developing an Audit and Assurance Policy.
Considered improvements in third-party due diligence and compliance with sanctions regimes towards Russia.
Conducted an annual review of progress against the business integrity areas.
Recommended the Audit & Risk Committee report for approval by the Board.
Held discussions with the external auditors and Head of IA without management present.
Considered technical accounting matters and their appropriate disclosure.
Supported the Board in discussions on fraud and whistleblowing.

The Committee increased the salary of both the CEO and CFO by 3.5%, which is below the budgeted 5% increase for UK employees.
Adjusted the overall mix of financial and non-financial measures from 80%-20% to 70%-30%.
The weighting will remain unchanged at 50% EPS, 20% TSR, 20% strategic, and 10% ESG.
The pension contribution for all Executive Directors must be aligned to the rate applying to the majority of the UK workforce (currently 5% of salary).

data.value: The policy is straightforward and clearly disclosed.
The policy is aligned with market practice.
Incentive plans are subject to maximum caps.
Appropriate balance between fixed and performance-based pay.
Sufficient to attract, retain and motivate high-calibre individuals
Reviewed annually with any increases normally taking effect from 1 December
Increases will normally be equivalent to the average salary increase for employees, other than in exceptional circumstances
Including benefits allowance, private medical insurance, permanent health insurance, life assurance and housing allowance (if relocated)
Cost of insured benefits will vary in line with premiums. Other benefits will be at a level considered appropriate in the circumstances
To provide a competitive pension provision
Individuals may either participate in a pension plan into which the Group contributes or receive a salary supplement in lieu of pension
Executive Directors are entitled to a Group contribution to a pension scheme or cash in lieu, of 5% of salary, aligned with the current UK workforce contribution
Incentivises high levels of personal and team performance
Deferral into shares for one third of any bonus earned, which must be held for two years
Maximum bonus opportunity is 120% of annual salary
Achievement of agreed strategic and financial/operational annual business targets, majority based on financial metrics
Incentivises and rewards Executives for the delivery of longer-term strategic objectives
LTIP awards normally vest after three years with two-year holding period
150% of salary p.a. in normal circumstances, up to 175% in exceptional circumstances
Majority based on Group financial performance and shareholder value-based outcomes
Support and encourage share ownership by employees at all levels.

Individuals may participate in share plans offered on an 'all-employee' basis on the same terms as other colleagues. HMRC approved SAYE and SIP participation is available to all UK employees, including Executive Directors, on similar terms.
In line with statutory limits or lower limits specified by the Group from time to time.
Directors' interests with those of investors.

expected to build and maintain a shareholding equivalent in value to no less than 200% of base salary. Until this threshold is achieved Executive Directors are normally required to retain no less than 50% of the net of tax value from vested LTIP, deferred bonus or other share awards (after the expiry of any relevant holding period). After ceasing employment Executive Directors must normally retain a level of shareholding for two years equivalent to the lower of 200% of salary or the level of shareholding on ceasing employment with the Group. Self-purchased shares are excluded.

Climate Change Consideration and Executive Compensation

data.value: The management team has considered the impact of climate change in preparing the Consolidated Financial Statements, particularly in the context of the risks identified in the TCFD report.
Some performance conditions of the Long-Term Incentive Plan for members of the Executive Committee are linked and measured against ESG metrics from the 2022 financial year.
The ESG-related performance condition constitutes only 10% of each grant, the impact is considered immaterial.
The accounting policies are consistent with those applied in the previous financial year.

elements.title: Financial Statements Independent auditors’ report to the members of SThree plc

data.value: Directors are responsible for the preparation of the financial statements in accordance with the applicable framework.
Directors are responsible for internal controls necessary for preparation of financial statements free from material misstatement.
Directors are responsible for assessing the group’s and the company’s ability to continue as a going concern.
Auditors are responsible for obtaining reasonable assurance that the financial statements are free from material misstatement.
To issue an auditors’ report including their opinion on whether the financial statements are free from material misstatement.
Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are material if they could influence economic decisions.
Related to employment laws and indirect taxes impacting the territories in which the group operates.
Including enquiries with management and testing for provisions related to fraud or non-compliance.

Our principal risks include macro-economic environment/cyclicality, future growth, commercial relationships and customer risk, contractual liability, people, talent acquisition and retention, cyber security, data privacy, regulatory compliance, strategic change management, health and safety.
Impact of macroeconomic uncertainty due to the war in Ukraine.
Each risk has a named owner with sponsorship by a member of the Executive Committee.
Likelihood and impact assessed using a five-by-five scoring matrix.
Defined at principal risk level and categorized into five levels.
Displayed in data format, showing deviation from the risk appetite.
SThree seeks to ensure that its contractual exposure to claims is effectively controlled through its contracts.

Stable. The strategic shift towards enterprise clients and MSPs, which typically seek to apply their own contractual terms, presents negotiation challenges for SThree. We continue to proactively monitor and track this risk.
Contract approval processes are in place with defined escalation procedures for the proposal of contractual terms that do not align with standard negotiation parameters.
apply their own contractual terms, presents negotiation challenges for SThree. We continue to proactively monitor and track this risk. We work closely with each business.
business risks and associated contractual requirements.
profile of our customer contracts. This is supported by an approval framework.

The Company seeks to place the responsibility for supervision and control of contractors directly with the client, including the acceptance of liability for any acts, defaults or omissions.
Global insurance coverage in place to cover exposure.

elements.title: Strategic Report Market overview continued Demographic changes

data.value: The world is facing a demographic challenge driven by an ageing population.
By 2030, 1.4 billion, or one in six people, in the world will be aged 60 years or over, expected to double to over 2 billion by 2050.
The proportion of people of working age globally is shrinking, while the number of retirees is expanding.
This demographic shift is driving acute labour shortages across every sector.
Existing STEM talent is retiring, and there is insufficient entry of young people into STEM roles.
Employers will face pressure to get more out of fewer people, stay lean-staffed, and invest in developing young employees.
There is a rising demand for a highly skilled workforce and increased rates of pay, especially in STEM fields.
Over one-third of the US workforce identify as independent workers according to McKinsey.
62% of global executives believe freelancers will replace full-time employees within the next five years.
The move towards greater flexibility is a transformation in the working world since the pandemic.
55% of respondents in the recent research stated flexible working as one of their top three criteria.
Uniquely positioned to benefit from five megatrends driving STEM demand.
We are where the world comes for scarce STEM talent.
£30m Planned investment to increase productivity between 2022 and 2024.
Regular dividend in line with growing trading performance, targeting 33% to 40% of annual earnings for shareholders.
Digitalisation transformation is needed across all companies globally.

Fossil Fuel sector exposure Less than 3% of net fees globally are derived from oil and gas clients. Under a low-carbon transition potential net fees from these clients could be lost due to divestment and reduction in client demands. The risk would be two-fold on revenue and PERE.
% net fees generated from oil and gas sector.

In 2022, the ExCo agreed to an Energy Sector Position Statement for the business which outlined the key energy sector focus areas of the business. This enables leaders to grow our energy business informed by risk and with risk mitigation at front of thoughts. In addition, our clean energy network provides a forum for leaders to share insights and best practice on building clean energy business which contribute towards our target to double the size of clean energy.

Maintaining market share in rapidly expanding markets Through scenario analysis we have identified opportunities for significant growth, particularly under a renewable-led growth future (our scenario analysis of 1.5°C of warming with orderly growth). There is a potential risk that we do not respond quickly enough to maximise these opportunities and as a result lose market share. Decarbonisation continues to be a key megatrend in our business.

elements.title: Climate Change Risk and Opportunity Analysis

data.value: This table presents a comprehensive analysis of climate change-related risks and opportunities, structured across different scenarios (Renewable-led growth, Disruptive change, and Fossil-fuelled future) from 2025 to 2040. The impact is measured on a scale from very high risk (-£5m) to very high opportunity (+£20m). The table identifies key investment areas including wind, storage technology, resilient grid technology, and hydrogen across different geographical regions. It also addresses physical and policy/legal risks associated with climate change, particularly focusing on European markets and the decline in fossil fuel investments.
Investment areas include wind investment, storage technology, resilient grid technology, and hydrogen.
Includes physical risks from extreme weather and policy/legal risks from declining fossil fuel investments.

In accordance with the requirements of Section 172 of the Companies Act 2006 (the Act), the Directors confirm that during the financial year ended 30 November 2022 they have acted in a way that they consider, in good faith, would most likely promote the success of the Company for the benefit of its shareholders as a whole, having regard to the likely consequences of any decision in the long term and the broader interests of other stakeholders as required by the Act.

Supported by a well-established corporate governance framework, the Board’s decisions take the long-term interests of key stakeholders into account, including its employees, clients and candidates, shareholders and local communities.

Describe the potential impact of different scenarios, including a 2°C scenario, on the organisation’s businesses, strategy and financial planning. The TCFD recommendations require companies to include a scenario where the world is able to limit global temperature increases to 2°C above pre-industrial levels, or lower. Our scenarios, and the underlying data used in modelling, are based on the NGFS climate scenario framework which are categorised as follows: 1. Renewable-led growth (orderly, 1.5°C) 2. Disruptive change (disruptive 2°C) 3. Fossil-fuelled future (hot house 3°C+) 2021 – 2040 scenarios.
